data.title: Comparison Of Edgar Rice Burroughs's Film 'Tarzan Of The...
data.meta_description: Free Essay: Disney’s nineteen ninety-nine film, Tarzan is based of Edgar Rice Burroughs’s novel; Tarzan of the Apes. Tarzan has had many adaptions made from...
data.text:
Disney’s nineteen ninety-nine film, Tarzan is based of Edgar Rice Burroughs’s novel; Tarzan of the Apes. Tarzan has had many adaptions made from it over the years that range from comical to more serious tones. Thus, I thought it would be a good film to analyze. Despite it being a little outside the ten-year range, I felt that Disney’s adaption of Tarzan is a timeless classic. The movie takes place in a jungle somewhere in Africa, set between the late eighteen and early nineteen hundreds. Although Tarzan himself is not African, he has spent most of his life living in the jungles of Africa. Eventually, scientists come to study the gorillas that inhabit the jungle. Jane, one of the scientists on this expedition, happens upon Tarzan. She is surprised that he can communicate with her, saying “And all this time I thought you were just a big, wild, quiet, silent, person-thing.” Deducing that he is less than human because he does not communicate with her right away. When talking to her father, she refers to Tarzan as a “Wild Man” and “Ape Man” Clayton; Jane and her father’s bodyguard, refers to Tarzan as a “savage,” because he does not speak English. All of this, furthering the idea that Tarzan is less than human, because he is unlike them in his mannerisms and way of life.

While Jane and her father are talking about the discovery of Tarzan, her father exclaims that he is “A man with no language, human behavior, and no respect for personal boundaries.” Tarzan in fact has a
